awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Robust Nanofiltration to Enable Challenging Chemical and Pharmaceutical Separations
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase II project focuses on advancing the domestic manufacturing capabilities for high-value nanomaterials for new membrane materials. Previously, the company has developed a novel membrane material with considerable economic, environmental, and nutritional impact in industrial process applications. Commercially available nanofiltration (NF) membrane systems employ polymer membranes, which have inherent chemical and thermal intolerance and are therefore difficult to clean or cannot be used in all separation streams. Meanwhile, 12% of US energy consumption is dedicated to thermal separations, a number that can be cut by a factor of 10 with appropriate physical separation technologies. This technology has applications across food & beverage processing, pharmaceutical production, semiconductor manufacturing, and chemical/petrochemical refining.

Creating nanometer-scale features on large areas (tens of square meters) will enable technical opportunities for a multitude of products and applications. In this SBIR Phase II project, the company is conducting process development, pilot demonstration, and scale up efforts toward coating graphene oxide thin films for nanofiltration membrane separations applications. Today?s membrane processes are limited by the selectivity and durability of the nanofiltration membrane. Improved selectivity and operational conditions from the material platform enables improved downstream processes, and new product development. The technology is tolerant to elevated temperatures, extreme pH, organic and chlorinated solvents, and high levels of oxidizers. Transitioning from thermal separations to membrane separations saves 90% of the required energy. Meanwhile, payback time is < 3 months when improving clean-in-place (CIP) protocol for existing NF processes. This is a game changer for the separations industry. Key separations of interest include desalting, whey concentration, sugar fractionation, fatty acid separation, nutraceutical extraction, pharmaceutical purification and black liquor concentration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Via Separations has completed Phase I, Phase II and Phase IIB of its NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) grant. During Phase I, Via focused on building a novel graphene oxide (GO) membrane to meet customer separation requirements. This work was driven by customer interviews and aimed to address preliminary technical risk by demonstrating commercially relevant GO membrane applications at the bench scale. Via Separation's Phase II & Phase IIB efforts focused on delivering required advancements in nanomaterials, membrane design and membrane manufacturing. Collectively, the work supported by the NSF SBIR grant has supported Via's effort to become the first company to commercialize and scale large-area GO membranes.

Via Separations is proud of the significant progress achieved in conjunction with the NSF SBIR grant. We have developed the capability for in-house characterization of graphene oxide formulations and coating. This enabled us to build a fundamental understanding of the properties critical to membrane performance and allowed us to understand our needs for transitioning from lab-scale coating to continuous roll-to-roll processing. We have also developed roll-to-roll coating strategies for membrane production with three different manufacturing partners. By doing so we were able to de-risk our production process as well as fully explore the most effective formulations, substrate materials, and coating procedures. Finally, we expanded testing capability, with a focus on determining membrane performance in customer feed solutions, as well as custom-made synthetic analogs. 

Key results include identifying chemistries that provide excellent membrane performance and are amenable to roll-to-roll production, scaling our formulation to >100L batch sizes, progression from a 12" to 40" web width, and coating rolls up to 4000' in length. These quantities, in particular web width, reach the requirements needed for producing commercial-sized membrane modules. Meanwhile, our testing has demonstrated the performance of roll-to-roll coated material consistently matches that of lab scale samples. Finally, Via has focused on enhancing our quality control and consistency of roll-to-roll coatings in order to increase yield.

This scale-up has been essential in producing the spiral wound GO membrane modules that are a key component in our intended product: The Black Liquor Concentration System. The development of these first-of-their-kind modules has driven the deployment of Via's pilot Black Liquor Concentration System and forthcoming commercial systems. Advancing our development of large-area GO membranes has positioned Via to successfully raise a Series A and Series B equity round. It has also supported the development of trade secrets and the core manufacturing skillsets needed to enable the deployment of our technology across a number of sectors. Accelerating this development has accelerated Via's time to market and supports our mission to eliminate 500 MT of Carbon Dioxide by 2050 by reducing industrial energy use.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2022
Modified by: Shreya Dave
